descriptions.text: 'This subspecies occurs from San Francisco in California north to Corvallis, Oregon.  There is also apparently one population east of Fresno, California.'
'Found on steep sand banks of creeks and rivers, most commonly in the shade of trees.'
'Found in southern California, from just south of the Bay Area to the area around San Diego.'
'Found on steep sand or silt banks of creeks and rivers, often where shaded.'
'Body length 3.5 to 4.5 mm, with most specimens longer than 3.9 mm.'
'Found from southern California north to Corvallis, Oregon.'
'Found on steep, sand or silt banks of creeks and rivers, frequently in the shade of trees. '
'Body length 3.5-4.5 mm, with most specimens 3.8-4.2 mm.'
'This species is known from the southern Sierra Nevada mountains, north to Volcanic Lassen National Park and west to the Trinity Alps in Northern California.'
'This species lives in North America from Colorado and New Mexico west through Arizona and Utah to southern California.  There are also populations in northern Baja California in Mexico.'

'As is typical for members of subgenus Liocosmius, B. horni occurs on sand or silt shores of creeks and rivers, especially where the bank is steep, and more frequently in shaded areas. For example, under the route 211 bridge over the Gila River in New Mexico, B. horni is common (along with B. "Cooper's") on the bank shown in the following picture: '
'Body length is 3.2 - 4.1 mm, with larger specimens being found east of California.'
'From the Roanoke River drainage in Virginia south in the Piedmont through North Carolina, South Carolina, Alabama, and Mississippi (Fig. 23). Approximately 580 specimens were studied.'

'Less gravel-or cobble-dependent than most Pseudoperyphus. The most notable feature in common to known sites is the presence of pure, well-drained sand. At some of the known localities this sand has fine gravel mixed in, but at others, including the type locality, the beetles are found on pure sand or sand containing layers of leaf litter, in which the beetles hide. Near Wiggins, Mississippi, and at six of the nine localities in Virginia and North Carolina, specimens were found in the company of an undescribed species related to B. aenulum (maddison and Arnold, in prep.) which itself prefers coarse, well-drained sand shores.'

'Three genes show fixed differences between the Mississippi populations and the North Carolina/Virginia populations: 18S rDNA, differing by one nucleotide; CAD, also differing by one nucleotide; COI, with the populations differing at five nucleotide sites. The population from Mississippi is distinct enough from the North Carolina and Virginia populations in DNA sequences that it may eventually warrant a separate name. However, geographically intermediate localities should be sampled before this is done.'

'Members of the subgenus Liocosmius live in North America from northern Baja California, east to New Mexico, Colorado, and Idaho, and north and west to British Columbia.  The greatest diversity is found in California, where all but one species live.'

'With one exception, the habit of Liocosmius is similar among the species: steep, sand or silt banks of rivers and creeks, usually in partly shaded areas.  The one exception is Bembidion "SierraStar", which also occurs on richer organic soil of high-elevation lakes in the Sierra Nevada of California. '
